1.47.text:
- [Announcer] The following   
  program is a production

49.68.text:
- Hello, and welcome to     
    Compass, a production

53.62.text:
I'm Les Heen, your       
       host for Compass.

55.62.text:
This is a weekly              
  discussion of public policy

57.49.text:
and important issues        
    facing our viewing area.

59.93.text:
This week we will look at       
what's new in the dairy industry

64.20.text:
We'll see how farmers are    
   keeping up with demands

67.13.text:
And working through what could 
 be some challenging times.

70.24.text:
First we have the story      
   of how a family dairy farm

73.61.text:
near Chokio, Minnesota moved  
  into the automated side

77.64.text:
For a closer look at       
     how that farm has seen

81.98.text:
here's a report from      
      Laura Kay Prosser.

85.72.text:
- The Blackwelders have       
  been farming their homestead

90.59.text:
But it wasn't until 1960    
    when the family started

93.43.text:
focusing on dairy         
      that the beef cattle

96.23.text:
and the pigs were weaned     
   out and the milking parlor

100.33.text:
Here's their story of      
     how that parlor got

104.84.text:
- My grandfather,        
       he took a big step

106.84.text:
and put a milking         
      parlor in, in 1969,

109.78.text: and redid the barn to fit that.

112.04.text:
He just enjoyed the        
     cows more than swine.

115.88.text:
They had some swine         
    when my dad was little,

117.38.text:
But he really didn't      
      care for the hogs.

119.69.text:
That's when we really        
   started focusing on dairy

121.32.text:
and making that their main   
   part of the operation.

126.83.text: My dad redid the parlor in 1995.

130.06.text:
He put new equipment       
     in and made it larger.

132.37.text:
We took automatic take-offs    
 so that the parlor could sense

136.90.text: when each cow was done milking.

138.54.text:
It was less watching      
      the flow of the milk

140.64.text: to try to take it off.

142.58.text:
So the parlor took       
       care of itself.

144.58.text: Each unit had its own sensor.

146.41.text:
That's better for the      
     cows' udder health.

150.08.text:
- [Laura Kay] But what      
    does an automated system

153.19.text:
- What it is, it's       
       a robotic milker.

155.42.text:
It preps the udder,        
     stimulates the udder,

158.76.text:
disinfects the             
     udder, gets it clean.

160.43.text:
Then it attaches and         
   collects the milk for us.

163.00.text:
So we aren't moving them    
    around like we used to.

165.33.text:
When we were in the parlor,   
  we would bring the cows

167.30.text: to the parlor three times a day.

170.27.text:
Now the cow goes to the       
  robot whenever she pleases.

173.37.text:
She's not milked every     
     single time she goes

175.44.text:
to the robot, and         
      sometimes some cows

177.38.text:
don't go to the robot      
     as much as we'd like

179.61.text:
so we bring them           
     there and helping them

181.85.text:
or pushing them pretty     
     much into the robot

184.25.text: so they get used to it.

187.62.text:
Five years ago we installed   
  an automatic calf feeder.

192.12.text:
Our cows that weren't       
    on the automatic feeder,

194.13.text:
they were more stubborn to    
  go into the robot at first.

198.30.text:
But it seemed like these     
   younger ones they remember

200.43.text:
from being a calf that      
    they got fed in a stall.

203.20.text:
Well now they're in a       
    stall, it's just larger.

205.94.text:
Other than the first milking   
 which when we help the robot,

208.24.text:
we do not have to touch a      
 cow when it comes to milking.

215.45.text:
It's just way             
      better for the cow.

216.95.text:
Also, it's better          
     for their production.

219.32.text:
We get more production out    
  of these cows because of it.

221.52.text:
- [Laura Kay] So what does   
   this mean for an average

227.06.text:
- Each cow has an             
  electronic tag on the collar

229.60.text:
on its neck and that      
      tag has a pedometer.

233.07.text:
So if her activity goes     
    down it will flag it

237.20.text:
Then also it counts       
      her rumination,

240.07.text:
which is how many minutes    
   a day she's eating

243.78.text:
So if she has a ruminating     
 average of 450 minutes a day,

246.65.text:
and one day she goes down    
   to 200, it will flag it

249.92.text:
and we can go and        
       check the cow out.

252.82.text:
It usually will show us she's  
 sick before she will show

255.89.text: visual signs of her being sick.

258.12.text:
We catch things quicker, and  
  the sicknesses don't take

260.43.text:
as large as a toll as they   
   would if we would have

262.83.text:
probably waited another      
   day before we can actually

265.97.text:
visually see that her ears   
   are down or she puffing.

268.27.text:
Before we can visually     
     see a sickness

271.57.text:
the robot and the           
    computer find it for us.

274.81.text:
From this system we went to     
five full-time employees to two.

278.98.text:
We cut down on our labor    
    force dramatically,

284.05.text:
What we really did is      
     we took the three jobs

285.42.text:
that we took away, the      
    money that we were using

287.55.text:
to pay them is now going     
   to make the loan payments

292.02.text:
- [Laura Kay] Just because   
   the farm is a little

294.19.text:
more automated than         
    most, and seems straight

296.43.text:
out of the future, it doesn't  
 mean the Blackwelder family

299.10.text:
can just sit back and let     
  the robots do all the work.

303.60.text:
- We've always, ever       
     since I can remember,

306.07.text:
my father's always really    
   focused on genetics

308.57.text:
and always trying to      
      breed a better cow,

313.78.text:
We've always tried to stay   
   upbeat with technology

316.35.text:
and try to keep up with         
industry and not dragged behind.

320.39.text:
I always looks for new       
   ways to be more productive

323.66.text:
A lot of people say       
      you have robots,

325.36.text: you don't have to work anymore.

326.86.text:
No, the only thing that a     
  robot does is milk the cows.

330.00.text:
It gives them a treat,      
    but it doesn't feed them

332.06.text:
the rest of their         
      nutrients they need.

335.90.text:
We're still here all      
      the time, it seems.

405.07.text:
- And with us now to         
   discuss any other changes

406.57.text:
in the dairy industry, we    
   have from South Dakota,

410.74.text:
And he's with the South Dakota 
 Department of Agriculture.

413.21.text:
And from Minnesota we have   
   the Associate Director

415.58.text:
of the Minnesota Milk      
     Producers Association,

419.79.text:
And I should mention Eir     
   is also with the Minnesota

423.69.text:
So Dave, Eir, thanks      
      for being with us.

426.39.text:
- Eir, I'd like          
       to start with you.

427.76.text:
I know you've got Minnesota   
  Milk and you've got

431.26.text:
Tell us a little bit      
      about what you do

434.13.text:
- With Midwest Dairy         
   Association we really work

436.77.text:
on building sales and       
    trust for dairy farmers.

440.01.text:
We work on helping dairy    
    farmers secure future

446.91.text:
There's a lot of          
      innovation going on

450.85.text:
We also work within our        
 schools and helping make sure

453.45.text:
everyone really understands   
  that getting three dairy

456.36.text:
servings a day is          
     what's really needed.

461.69.text:
Then with Minnesota Milk,    
   we work with dairy farms

465.00.text:
specifically on helping them  
  with educational programming

467.27.text:
to be more successful      
     in their farms.

469.97.text:
Then also representing       
   their needs at the capital

473.67.text:
in terms of legislature and   
  programs and assistance.

477.48.text:
- Okay, great, and Dave,    
    South Dakota Department

480.78.text: You've been there for a while

481.85.text:
and you're a specialist     
    in dairy, right?

483.28.text:
- Right I have been,       
     I've been working with

488.29.text:
Came in doing the dairy      
   development specifically.

491.66.text:
I've had the opportunity    
    to watch the industry

494.99.text:
grow tremendously in       
     South Dakota and also

498.86.text:
- Let's talk about       
       trends for a bit.

501.17.text:
I was thinking about       
     how many people I know

502.50.text:
who may have grown        
      up on a dairy farm,

504.00.text:
or their friends were on a    
  dairy farm but they've been

505.67.text: away from it for a while.

507.07.text:
If you go onto a         
       dairy farm today,

509.11.text:
things may seem            
     very, very different.

511.38.text:
So tell us about some        
   trends that you're seeing

512.95.text:
in South Dakota          
       for dairy farming.

514.45.text:
- One of the big things is    
  I think that we're starting

516.95.text:
to see more people that have,  
 their families have left

520.52.text:
the dairy industry         
     and have gone off into

523.49.text:
other sectors to get        
    their education and work

526.53.text:
are now starting to trend    
   back coming into the farm.

529.93.text:
As our dairies have          
   continued to grow in size,

534.87.text: it's a labor issue as well.

537.84.text:
But the main thing is      
     it's a quality of life

539.84.text:
for these people, and          
 especially for the young ones

542.11.text:
coming back they may      
      have young families.

546.71.text:
They're getting a chance    
    to come back closer

548.61.text: to grandma and grandpa as well,

550.35.text:
and get back into the        
   business they grew up in.

552.79.text:
- And Eir, I know when we    
   were having a break there

555.69.text:
for a moment, you talked    
    about you were seeing

557.39.text:
the same kind of          
      thing in Minnesota.

559.52.text:
And in many cases          
     it's technology            
     that's sort of helping

561.43.text:
to enable people to         
    come back in and partner

563.63.text:
in some ways that maybe      
   they didn't before, right?

567.47.text:
I think that we've been       
  seeing a lot of young people

570.34.text:
wanting to get back       
      into the business.

572.01.text:
They're coming back       
      to the dairy farms.

574.31.text:
The utilization of             
 technology and multi families

578.28.text:
working together is          
   really helping them to be

580.55.text:
more efficient and        
      more specialized in       
      what they're doing.

583.92.text:
- I want to pick up on

because someone who was

589.29.text:
once wrote an essay called,

She talked about cows

595.79.text:
that in dairy farming there

601.13.text:
You're there on the farm

But is the multi-family

611.98.text:
Because then you

I think that it also just       
helps with that specialization.

One family might be really   
   interested in caring

623.42.text:
for the cows, so they focus

Another family might be     
    specifically interested

629.96.text:
in the crops and           
     maintaining that land

It allows them to focus

635.94.text:
are interested in and          
 specializing in and so forth.

640.14.text:
I think that's kind of     
     the large part of it.

642.88.text:
- I don't know, Dave       
     you've had some people

644.11.text:
that sort of come back      
    to the farm as you said

647.78.text:
How are people doing      
      some of those things

650.18.text:
- I think Eir's right on it

652.35.text:
that have come back to     
     the farm and they have

657.32.text:
whether it's taking       
      care of baby calves.

And today as our operations

662.36.text:
you also have the need     
     for somebody to be

667.33.text:
There's so many rules and

671.17.text:
They're having to spend     
    more time on these

675.11.text:
- Sure, and I suppose

676.58.text:
on a farm and it was

678.85.text:
as much help, you didn't have

because you were

But now you're maybe

685.48.text:
and the high specialization

687.82.text:
- Exactly, and the thing is,  
  the technology has changed

691.26.text:
so much over the last just   
   10 years in the industry.

695.13.text:
I mean, it's when you see      
 cows that are wearing collars

700.80.text:
that keep track of       
       their ruminations

705.14.text:
But it's all about cow     
     comfort and the health

708.24.text:
of the animal and making

711.01.text:
- And that's I think, one    
   of the things that I think

714.01.text:
people would be           
      most surprised about

715.65.text:
if they looked at         
      a modern dairy farm

717.22.text:
is the technology changes    
   because there have been

721.35.text:
Who would have thought about   
 a pedometer years ago, right?

724.49.text:
- No, it's just another way    
 of monitoring a cow's health,

727.03.text:
making sure that if       
      she's not getting in

734.03.text: see if she's got a sore foot.

You know, maybe had            
 something, a little arthritis

739.91.text:
starting to come into

742.21.text:
Just to make sure that

744.58.text:
- Now when you talk

746.34.text:
a lot of people might

Because, of course, people

in technology that

So how does all of this

757.86.text:
affect the profits

762.60.text:
- I think yeah, there's always 
 a cost associated with it.

765.06.text:
But the cost, it can

769.40.text:
on the investment,       
       the cow comfort,

771.64.text:
and the information       
      they're getting back

773.57.text:
out of the data to make

778.31.text:
on what they're going to

780.45.text: that day or the next day.

782.45.text: So I mean yeah, it plays a role.

- Sure, and I expect we're    
  also seeing people come back

It could be Ag Marketing,

It could be one of the         
 specialists you talked about.

So people come back

on how to approach farming

798.90.text:
- Yeah they do, and        
     I think a lot of them

are more working

I see a lot of farmers

and their veterinarians,

and figure out what's

at the same table, let's

819.85.text:

in the dairying, it was

That was a little bit

Maybe a little bit

But, let's talk about some

Dave, you've traveled,

We attend the World Ag

With attending those

about recruiting cows

I want to recruit

But it's about recruiting      
 cows for the area, the region.

867.00.text:
When you sit here and      
     you look and really

869.97.text:
there's no border difference  
  between South Dakota

We have plenty of forages, we  
 have good water sources here.

We have an excellent

And these things

So as far as recruiting

Minnesota, Iowa, and North    
  Dakota we're all pretty much

We've got advantages that

We've got water where

They've got other              
 regulations, political issues

I think we're in a very

908.54.text:
for people to move their

or to South Dakota and

916.35.text:
of life, raise a family

- You mentioned California,

someone telling me about

of course they have a

those very large farms

between California and

When people have those

But I think the

people have to get used

when you get a number

probably about like dairy

where you've got a lot

and you have a dairy

suddenly other things

with plentiful land and

 regional variations of course,

So developing that niche

who may have a

1160.69.text:

as people look at

our dairy processing

And yes the trends

1262.19.text:
I think there's a lot of

whether you're a small

Because of course, we're

1285.78.text:
and quality control

different types of

Once the cow's comfortable

1322.52.text:
As long as your providing

of time to rest in clean

1362.53.text:
